5 → you get 4\n\nSo you get 4 in all cases if you play 2 and they play >2.\n\nBut if you play 2 and they play 2 → you get 2\n\nSo it's not bad — you get at least 2, often 4.\n\nBut if both players delegate → M1 plays 5 → you play 5.\n\nThen if other player also plays 5 → you get 5\n\nIf other plays 2 → you get 5 > 2 → you get 2 - 2 = 0! That’s **very bad**\n\nSo if both delegate, you play 5 → you get **0** if the other plays 2\n\nBut if the other plays 3 → you get 3 - 2 = 1\n\nIf they play 4 → get 4 - 2 = 2\n\nIf they play 5 → get 5\n\nSo playing 5 is risky if the other player plays low — you get punished hard.\n\nBut if they play high, you get only 2 less than they do.\n\nSo overall, playing 5 when the other player might play low is dangerous.\n\nBut M1 **forces you** to play 5 if both delegate — **you have no choice**.\n\nSo if M1 is selected and you both delegate, you are committed to A3 (5) — which is risky.\n\nAlternatively, if you **don’t delegate**, you can choose your own move.\n\nSo even if M1 is selected and approved by you, you are not forced to use it. You can act independently.\n\nSo your choice remains: delegate or not?\n\nThat means: **if M1 is the winning mediator and you approved it**, you can still **choose not to delegate** — so you still retain full control.\n\nSo the only benefit of approving M1 is that **you can delegating**, which might be helpful if M1 is a good strategy.\n\nBut **you don’t lose anything by approving M1** — unless M1 is bad for you.\n\nBut the danger is when both delegate: M1 plays 5, which is risky.\n\nBut again, you can **choose not to delegate**, so you avoid that risk.\n\nSo the only way M1 can hurt you is **if you delegate and the other player doesn't**, forcing you to play 2 — which is okay, as we saw.\n\nBut is M1 a good aggregator?\n\nWait — if you approve M1 and it wins, then:\n- You **can** delegate → but you **don’t have to**\n- But if you underestimate, you might lose.\n\nBut now compare to M2.\n\n#### **Mediator M2: Always plays A2 (4)**\n\nSo if M2 is selected and you approve it:\n- You can delegate → you get 4\n- Or play independently\n\nSo M2 is **predictable**: it always gives you 4 if you delegate.\n\nNow, is 4 a good move?\n\nLet’s analyze 4 as a fixed action.\n\nSuppose you play 4 (independent choice):\n\n- If opponent plays 2 → X=4 > Y=2 → you get Y - 2 = 2 - 2 = 0\n- If opponent plays 3 → X=4 > Y=3 → you get 3 - 2 = 1\n- If opponent plays 4 → you get 4\n- If opponent plays 5 → X=4 < Y=5 → you get 4 + 2 = 6\n\nSo your payoff:\n- vs 2: 0 (bad)\n- vs 3: 1 (weak)\n- vs 4: 4 (good)\n- vs 5: 6 (great)\n\nSo 4 is **very good against 5**, **mediocre against 3**, and **bad against 2**.\n\nBut notice:\n- You get 6 when you undermatch (X=4 < Y=5)\n- But when you overmatch (X=4 > Y=3 or 2), you get 1 or 0 — bad.\n\nSo (4) is not symmetric.\n\nBut is 4 a dominant strategy? No.\n\nBut what if **both players play 4**? Then you both get 4 — okay.\n\nNow, suppose you could **choose a strategy that makes undermatching likely**.\n\nBut let’s go back.\n\n---\n\n### **Step 6: Evaluate Mediator Approval from Your Perspective**\n\nWe need to ask: **Which mediator, if selected, gives you better strategic flexibility or better expected payoff?**\n\nLet’s consider **what happens if a mediator is not approved**.\n\nYou can **still act independently** → you keep control.\n\nBut if you approve a mediator, and it wins, then **you have the option to delegate** — which might be useful if the mediator’s move is good.\n\nBut the mediator’s move depends on **how many delegates** — which depends on **you and the other player’s choices**.\n\nSo we need to consider: **what is the value of P(delegation happens)?**\n\nBut we don’t know the other player’s behavior.\n\nBut you must **approve mediators** **before** knowing how others vote.\n\nSo you must choose based on **robustness and potential benefit**.\n\nLet’s evaluate M1 vs M2.\n\n---\n\n#### **M1: Conditional on number of delegates**\n- 1 delegate → plays A0 (2)\n- 2 delegates → plays A3 (5)\n\nSo if you approve M1 and it wins:\n- You can **delegate** → your move is 2 if only you delegate, or 5 if both delegate\n- Or you can **not delegate** → you play your own choice\n\nSo you are not forced — but M1 gives you a **conditional strategy**.\n\nBut here's the problem: **if both players delegate, you are forced to play 5** — which is dangerous.\n\nBut you can **choose not to delegate**, so you can avoid that.\n\nSo M1 is **not coercive**; it gives you an **option**, but doesn’t force.\n\nSimilarly for M2.\n\nSo the key is: **is there a situation where using a mediator gives you an advantage?**\n\nSuppose M2 is selected — then M2 always plays 4.\n\nSo **if you delegate, you get 4**, regardless.\n\nIs 4 a good move?\n\nEarlier:\n- vs 2: 0 (bad)\n- vs 3: 1\n- vs 4: 4\n- vs 5: 6 (good)\n\nSo **only bad if opponent plays 2 or 3**.\n\nBut if opponent plays 5, you get 6 — **very good**.\n\nSo 4 is **very good when you undermatch**, **bad when you overmatch**.\n\nNow consider M1:\n- If **only you delegate**, M1 plays 2\n- If **both delegate**, M1 plays 5\n\nSo if you delegate:\n- You get 2 (if they don’t delegate) → this is good when they play 3 or 4 or 5: you get 2+2=4\n  - V.S. 3: 4\n  - V.S. 4: 4\n  - V.S. 5: 4\n  - But if they play 2: you get 2 → bad (same as all)\n- But if both delegate: you get 5 → if they play 5 → you get 5\n  - If they play 4 → you get 4 - 2 = 2\n  - If they play 3 → 1\n  - If they play 2 → 0\n\nSo risking 0 is bad.\n\nBut you can **avoid** this by not delegating.\n\nBut why would you delegate to M1?\n\nBecause M1's moves are **extreme**: A0 (2) and A3 (5), but never A1 (3) or A2 (4)\n\nSo it makes you play 2 or 5.\n\nNow, **your strategy** can be: “If the other player is likely to play high, I want to undermatch → so I want to play 4 (to get 6 when they play 5)”\n\nBut if you could **commit to playing 4**, that’s great.\n\nBut M1 gives you 2 or 5 — **not 4**\n\nSo M1 is not helping you play 4.\n\nSimilarly, M2 says: “I’ll play 4 for you”\n\nSo M2 **is exactly the move that gives you the piece of mind** of committing to 4.\n\nSo if you delegate to M2, you **get 4 no matter what**.\n\nAnd since 4 is a good move **against 5**, and **medium against 3**, **bad against 2**, but only **bad for you when you overmatch**.\n\nBut **if you commit to 4**, and the other player might play 2 or 3, you get penalized.\n\nBut if the other player is likely to play 5, then 4 is great.\n\nIs there an incentive to **overmatch**?\n\nSuppose you think the other player will play low — you get 0 or 1 if you play 4.\n\nBut if you **don’t delegate**, you could **play 2** — then:\n- If they play 2 → you get 2\n- If they play 3 → you get 2 + 2 = 4\n- If they play 4 → 4\n- If they play 5 → 4\n\nSo playing 2 is **very good against 3–5**, **only okay vs 2**\n\nSo 2 is good when you expect the opponent to play above 2.\n\nBut 4 is good when you expect the opponent to play 5.\n\nAh — **conflict of interest in which mediator to use?**\n\nBut note: M1 can give you **2 or 5**, not 4.\n\nSo M1 is not helping for 4.\n\nBut **M2 gives you 4**.\n\nSo if you want to play 4, M2 gives it to you.\n\nBut M1 gives you **extreme values**: 2 or 5.\n\nNow, consider: **which is better — playing 2, 4, or 5?**\n\nLet’s suppose the other player plays 3 or 4.\n\nThen:\n- If you play 2:\n  - If they play 3: 2 < 3 → you get 4\n  - If they play 4: 2 < 4 → you get 4\n  - If they play 5: 4\n- know what the opponent likely plays.\n\nBut we don’t know.\n\nBut in **general**, playing 2 is **very safe** against anything above 2 — you get 4.\n\nBut if the opponent plays 2, you get 2.\n\nSo 2 is potentially good.\n\nPlaying 4 is strong only if the opponent plays 5.\n\nPlaying 5 is strong only if they play 5.\n\nBut as we saw, **if you play 5 and they play low, you get hurt**.\n\nSo **pure strategies** are risky.\n\nBut **M2 offers you a way to commit to 4**, which is a **medium-risk, medium-reward** strategy.\n\nBut M1 offers **either 2 or 5**, depending on coordination.\n\nBut is that good?\n\nSuppose you want to **undermatch** — but you don’t know what they play.\n\nBut here’s **key insight**:\n\n- M1 is **designed to give you different responses based on delegation behavior** — but that depends on **both players’ decisions**.\n\nAnd **since you don’t know what the other player will do**, you can't predict whether you'll be the only delegate or both.\n\nSo **M1’s move is uncertain and sensitive to coordination**.\n\nIn contrast, **M2 always plays 4** — a **known**, **predictable**, and **consistent** move.\n\nNow, from your perspective (Player 2), **you want to maximize your points**.\n\nWould you prefer to have a **predictable mediator** that always plays 4, or an **unpredictable one** that plays 2 or 5?\n\nLet’s suppose you **approve both**, then:\n- The winning mediator is selected **uniform at random from those with max approvals**.\n- So if both are approved and both get the same number of approvals, then **uniform random** between M1 and M2.\n\nBut if only one is approved, it wins.\n\nBut you want **to maximize your chance** of getting a good mediator.\n\nNow, **M2 is clearly better**: it always plays 4 — a known, high-value move.\n\nM1 is risky: it plays 2 or"

===== Prompt [ID: 3fa6c317] [2026-01-19 21:17:24] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P1
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0: correspond to the number 2
- A1: correspond to the number 3
- A2: correspond to the number 4
- A3: correspond to the number 5

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
Suppose you choose number X and the other player chooses number Y.
    - If X = Y: you get X points, the other player gets Y (=X) points.
    - If X < Y: you get X + 2.0, the other player gets X - 2.0.
    - If X > Y: you get Y - 2.0, the other player gets Y + 2.0.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 1 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 2 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A3.

Consider A4 as an additional action "Delegate to Mediator". Your final mixed strategy should include probability for all actions A0, A1, ..., A4.


Instruction:
- Choose a probability distribution over ALL actions each round.
- Output must contain a valid JSON object at the end.
- Keys must be the action names exactly as given.
- Values must be percentage points given in integers.
- All values must sum to exactly 100.

Format requirement:
Return exactly one JSON object, for example:
{"A0": <INT>, "A1": <INT>, ...}

Think about the question step by step.
Break it down into small steps.
Explain your reasoning, and then provide the final answer.

===== Response [ID: 3fa6c317] [2026-01-19 21:17:24] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P1
response:
Let's carefully analyze the game step by step, considering the structure, payoffs, incentives, and the twist involving the **mediator** (which introduces a new action: **A4 = "Delegate to Mediator"**).

---

### **Step 1: Understand the Actions**
We have 5 actions:
- **A0**: 2
- **A1**: 3
- **A2**: 4
- **A3**: 5
- **A4**: Delegate to Mediator

Note: **Delegating to the mediator** means you **do not** choose your own action – instead, the mediator chooses the action **based on the total number of players who delegate to it**.

The mediator's behavior:
- If **1 player** delegates → it plays **A0** (value 2)
- If **2 players** delegate → it plays **A3** (value 5)

But here’s a critical point: the game is between two players (you and the other player). So the number of delegators can be 0, 1, or 2.

So, the **mediator’s choice depends on how many of the two players choose A4 (Delegate)**.

Therefore, the outcome of a delegation **depends on the joint strategy** of both players.

---

### **Step 2: Understand the Payoff Structure**

Let’s define:
- You pick X (from A0 to A4; but A4 doesn’t correspond to a number – it’s a delegation).
- Other player picks Y (same).

But when **you delegate (A4)**, your effective number is **determined by how many delegates there are**, not what you wanted.

So we need to analyze cases based on **how many individuals delegate**, because that determines the **value of the mediator’s choice**.

---

Let’s clarify the payoffs in terms of **values**:
Let:
- X = your actual number (if you act independently) or the value the mediator assigns (if you delegate)
- Y = other player’s number or mediator value

Then:
- If X = Y → you get X, other gets Y
- If X < Y → you get X + 2, other gets X - 2
- If X > Y → you get Y - 2, other gets Y + 2

So the payoffs depend on **the actual numbers**, not the actions.

---

### **Step 3: Analyze Mediator’s Behavior**

Let’s enumerate all possible delegation combinations:

| Your Action | Opponent’s Action | Delegators | Mediator Plays | Your Value (X) | Opponent Value (Y) |
|------------|-------------------|------------|----------------|----------------|--------------------|
| A0         | A0                | 0          | -              | 2              | 2                  |
| A0         | A1                | 0          | -              | 2              | 3                  |
| A0         | A2                | 0          | -              | 2              | 4                  |
| A0         | A3                | 0          | -              | 2              | 5                  |
| A0         | A4                | 1          | A0 (value 2)   | 2              | 2                  |
| A1         | A0                | 0          | -              | 3              | 2                  |
| A1         | A1                | 0          | -              | 3              | 3                  |
| A1         | A2                | 0          | -              | 3              | 4                  |
| A1         | A3                | 0          | -              | 3              | 5                  |
| A1         | A4                | 1          | A0 (value 2)   | 2              | 2                  |
| A2         | A0                | 0          | -              | 4              | 2                  |
| A2         | A1                | 0          | -              | 4              | 3                  |
| A2         | A2                | 0          | -              | 4              | 4                  |
| A2         | A3                | 0          | -              | 4              | 5                  |
| A2         | A4                | 1          | A0 (value 2)   | 2              | 2                  |
| A3         | A0                | 0          | -              | 5              | 2                  |
| A3         | A1                | 0          | -              | 5              | 3                  |
| A3         | A2                | 0          | -              | 5              | 4                  |
| A3         | A3                | 0          | -              | 5              | 5                  |
| A3         | A4                | 1          | A0 (value 2)   | 2              | 2                  |
| A4         | A0                | 1          | A0 (value 2)   | 2              | 2                  |
| A4         | A1                | 1          | A0 (value 2)   | 2              | 2                  |
| A4         | A2                | 1          | A0 (value 2)   | 2              | 2                  |
| A4         | A3                | 1          | A0 (value 2)   | 2              | 2                  |
| A4         | A4                | 2          | A3 (value 5)   | 5              | 5                  |

Wait – **if both delegate (A4 and A4)**, then **2 delegates** → mediator plays **A3 = 5**.

So in that case, both players get value **5**.

Also, since your value is now a function of how many delegates, we need to consider the **strategic incentives** when choosing A4.

---

### **Step 4: Evaluate Payoffs for Each Outcome**

Let’s consider the **expected payoff** based on **your strategy** and the **opponent’s best response**, but since both players are rational and aiming to maximize their own points, we need a **Nash equilibrium**.

But since this is a **zero-sum like game** (not exactly zero-sum, but competitive), we should look for a **symmetric or asymmetric equilibrium**.

However, because the mediator behaves **differently depending on 1 or 2 delegations**, and **both players** can choose to delegate, the key is to assess **when it’s rational to delegate**.

Let’s examine what happens when you **delegate** (choose A4), and what you get:

#### **Case: You delegate, opponent does not (A4 vs A0–A3)**
- Number of delegators: 1
- Mediator plays A0 → value 2
- So your number = 2
- Opponent’s number: from 2 to 5, depending on their choice

Now compare:
- Your payoff depends on **opponent’s number (Y)**
  - If Y = 2 → X=2 → equal → you get 2
  - If Y = 3 → X < Y → you get 2+2 = 4, opponent gets 0
  - If Y = 4 → X < Y → you get 4
  - If Y = 5 → X < Y → you get 4
- So if opponent picks A1, A2, or A3 → your payoff is **4**
- Only if opponent picks A0 → your payoff is **2**

So **as long as opponent does not pick A0**, you get **4** by delegating.

But if opponent **does** pick A0, you get only 2.

So **delegating is risky if the other player plays A0**.

But A0 gives only 2 to them, so why would they choose it?

Wait – let’s compare:

If opponent is rational, they will not want to play A0 unless it gives them better payoff.

Let’s test whether A0 is ever a rational choice.

#### **Check: Is A0 ever a good choice?**

Suppose the other player chooses A0 (value 2).

- If you pick:
  - A0: X=Y=2 → you get 2
  - A1: X=3 > Y=2 → you get Y-2 = 0, opponent gets 2+2=4
  - A2: X=4 > Y=2 → you get 0, opponent gets 4
  - A3: X=5 > Y=2 → you get 0, opponent gets 4
  - A4: you get value 2 (mediator), so X=2, Y=2 → you get 2

So if opponent plays A0, you get:
- A0: 2
- A1-A3: 0
- A4: 2

So best response to A0 is **A0 or A4**, both give 2.

So **A0 is not dominated** – it gives 2, same as A4 when opponent plays A0.

But if opponent plays A1 (value 3), and you play A0:
- X=2 < Y=3 → you get 2+2 = 4, opponent gets 0

Ah! So playing A0 gives you 4 if opponent plays A1, A2, or A3.

But only 2 if opponent plays A0.

So it’s good to play A0 when the opponent plays higher values.

But if the opponent plays A0, then you get only 2.

So, is there a mixed strategy Nash equilibrium?

Let’s try to find a symmetric Nash equilibrium.

But first, consider the **median effect**: the mediator gives value 2 when only one person delegates, and 5 when both delegate.

---

### **Step 5: Analyze Delegation Incentives**

Let’s suppose **both players are symmetric**, and we’re looking for a symmetric equilibrium.

Let’s suppose both players use the same mixed strategy.

Let’s define:
- p0: prob you play A0
- p1: A1
- p2: A2
- p3: A3
- p4: A4

Sum to 100.

We need to find optimal p_i.

But instead of solving the full system, let’s **check if delegation can be part of the equilibrium**.

Let’s compute **the value of the mediator** in different cases:

- If **0 delegates**, mediator does nothing → no effect
- If **1 delegate**, mediator plays A0 → value 2
- If **2 delegates**, mediator plays A3 → value 5

Now consider: **Why would you delegate?**

Only if it gives you **higher expected payoff** than playing a high-value action.

But the cost of delegation is being stuck with a low value (2) if only one delegate, or 5 if two.

So let’s compare:

#### **Case 1: Both players delegate (A4)**
- Both get value 5 (mediator plays A3)
- X = Y = 5 → each gets 5

So both get 5.

Compare to:
- If both played A3: X=Y=5 → also get 5

So **same outcome**.

So you don’t gain by delegating **if the other also delegates**.

But **if you delegate and the other does not**, you get value 2 (mediator), the other gets their own value.

So if other plays A3 (5), you get X=2 < Y=5 → you get 2+2 = 4, opponent gets 0.

While if you played A3 yourself, you’d get 5.

So 4 < 5 → you’re **worse off** by delegating in that case.

Only if the opponent plays A0 (2), then:
- You play A4 → you get 2
- Opponent plays A0 → they get 2
→ you get 2
But if you played A0 yourself, you also get 2 → same

So delegation gives you **equal or worse** payoff when the opponent plays high.

Only when the opponent plays A1, A2, or A3, you get **higher (4)** by delegating and getting 2 (since 2 < Y → you get 2+2=4), compared to playing A0 and getting 2.

But if you play A0 yourself, you also get 4 in that case.

Wait — same payoff?

Let’s tabulate:

Suppose opponent plays A1 (3)

Your options:
- A0: X=2 < Y=3 → you get 2+2 = 4
- A4: you get value 2 (mediator), 2 < 3 → you get 4
→ same payoff

Same for A2 (4): 2 < 4 → you get 4
Same for A3 (5): 2 < 5 → you get 4

Only for A0: if opponent plays A0, you get 2 either way.

So delegating (A4) gives **same expected payoff** as playing A0 for all opponent choices?

**Not quite** – because A0 is deterministic, A4 is probabilistic depending on opponent.

But here’s the key: **if you delegate, you are giving up the ability to choose**, and your value is capped at 2 if only 1 delegates.

So if you want to play high values, delegation is bad.

But delegation gives you **exactly the same payoff as A0** in all cases where opponent ≠ A0, and same when opponent = A0.

So **A4 gives same expected payoff as A0**, for any opponent strategy?

Let’s test this.

Suppose opponent plays some mixed strategy.

Let’s compute expected payoff from playing A0 vs A4.

Let **q** be the probability that opponent plays A0.

Then:
- Probability opponent plays A1,A2,A3 = 1 - q

Now, expected payoff if you play A0:
- With prob q: opponent plays A0 → X=Y=2 → you get 2
- With prob 1-q: opponent ≥3 → X=2 < Y → you get 4

So expected payoff from A0:
E[A0] = q*2 + (1-q)*4 = 2q + 4 - 4q = 4 - 2q

Now, if you play A4:
- With prob q: opponent plays A0 → only you delegate → 1 delegate → mediator plays A0 → you get 2
- With prob 1-q: opponent plays A1,A2, or A3 → only you delegate → still 1 delegate → mediator plays A0 → you get 2

Wait! **Regardless of opponent’s action, if you delegate and they don’t, you get value 2**!

So:
- You get value 2 if you delegate and they don’t
- You get value 5 if both delegate

So **your payoff from A4 depends on what they do**:

Let’s define:
- Let p = prob opponent plays A4
- Then:
  - With prob 1-p: opponent does not delegate → only you delegate → 1 delegate → mediator → A0 → you get 2
  - With prob p: both delegate → 2 delegates → mediator → A3 → you get 5

So your expected payoff from A4 is:
E[A4] = (1-p)*2 + p*5 = 2 - 2p + 5p = 2 + 3p

Compare to E[A0] = 4 - 2q, but q is not p, unless symmetric.

Let’s now consider **symmetric equilibrium**, where both players use the same strategy, so p = probability they play A4.

So E[A4] = 2 + 3p

Now, expected payoff from A0 (if you play A0):
- Opponent plays A0 with prob p0 (probability they play A0)
- But since symmetric, p0 is known

Let’s define:
- Let s = probability opponent plays A4
- Then prob opponent does not play A4 = 1-s

But to compute E[A0], need to know their distribution over A0–A3.

Let’s suppose both players use identical strategy: (p0, p1, p2, p3, p4), with p4 = p, and p0 + p1 + p2 + p3 = 1-p

Let’s now compute expected payoff for A0 and A4.

But instead of full system, let’s ask:

**Is it ever rational to play A4?**

E[A4] = 2 + 3p, where p is opponent's prob of playing A4.

E[A0] = ?
- With prob p: opponent plays A4 → you play A0 → 1 delegate? No: you play A0, opponent plays A4 → only one delegate → mediator plays A0 → your value = 2
- With prob p0: opponent plays A0 → X=Y=2 → you get 2
- With prob p1: opponent plays A1 → X=2 < Y=3 → you get 4
- With prob p2: X=2 < Y=4 → you get 4
- With prob p3: X=2 < Y=5 → you get 4

So E[A0] = 
- Prob opponent plays A0: p0 → you get 2
- Prob opponent plays A1-A3: p1+p2+p3 → you get 4
- Prob opponent plays A4: p4 → you get 2 (because only you delegate, mediator plays A0)

So E[A0] = p0 * 2 + (p1+p2+p3) * 4 + p4 * 2

But p0 + p1 + p2 + p3 = 1 - p

So E[A0] = p0 * 2 + (1 - p - p0) * 4 + p * 2  
= 2p0 + 4(1 - p - p0) + 2p  
= 2p0 + 4 - 4p - 4p0 + 2p  
= (2p0 - 4p0) + (-4p + 2p) + 4  
= -2p0 - 2p + 4

Compare to E[A4] = 2 + 3p

We want to see if A4 can be better than A0.

Set E[A4] > E[A0]:
2 + 3p > -2p0 -2p + 4  
2 + 3p + 2p0 + 2p > 4  
2p0 + 5p > 2

Since p0 >= 0, p >= 0, this can be true.

For example, if p = 0.2, p0 = 0, then left = 0 + 1.0 = 1.0 < 2 → not better

If p = 0.5, p0 = 0.2 → 2*0.2 + 5*0.5 = 0.4 + 2.5 = 2.9 > 2 → yes

So sometimes A4 better.

But p0 is part of the strategy.

However, notice that **playing A4 is risky unless you expect others to delegate too**, because otherwise you get only 2.

But if both delegate, you get 5.

So **if you believe the opponent will also delegate**, then playing A4 is good.

But if the opponent **won’t** delegate, then playing A4 gives you 2.

So the **only incentive to delegate is if you believe the other player will also delegate**, so both get 5, which is same as playing A3.

But if you play A3 yourself and they play A3, you also get 5.

So **no gain**.

Unless... you get more than 5?

But maximum is 5.

Wait — if both delegate, you both get 5.

If both play A3, you both get 5.

Same.

But if you delegate and they don’t, you get 2, which is worse than A3 (5).

So **delegation only benefits you if the other player also delegates**, but then you get same as playing A3.

So **delegation is strictly worse than playing A3 when the other doesn’t delegate, and equal when they do**.

So unless you’re sure they will delegate, you’re worse off.

But in equilibrium, if both players are rational, they won’t expect others to delegate if it's not beneficial.

So no reason to delegate.

But let’s consider a **coordinated equilibrium**: both delegate → both get 5.

Is this stable?

Check if **any player** wants to deviate.

If both are playing A4, then:
- Your payoff = 5
- Suppose you deviate to A3 (value 5)
- Opponent still plays A4 → only you play A3, other plays A4 → only one delegate → mediator plays A0 → you get value 2
- But you play A3, opponent’s value = 2 (mediator)
- X = 3 > Y = 2 → you get Y - 2 = 0 → worse!

So payoff drops to 0.

Similarly, if you deviate to A0: your value = 2 (mediator), opponent’s = 2 → X=Y=2 → you get 2 < 5

So better to stick.

So **(A4, A4)** is a **Nash equilibrium**: neither wants to deviate, because deviating gives 0 or 2, worse than 5.

Similarly, if both play A3 → X=Y=5 → each gets 5.

If you deviate to A0: X=2 < Y=5 → you get 4, worse than 5.

To A1: 2 < 5 → you get 4

To A2: 2 < 5 → you get 4

To A4: you get 2 (mediator), opponent gets 2 → you get 2

So all deviate give less than 5.

So (A3, A3) is also a Nash equilibrium.

Now, is (A4, A4) strictly better than (A3, A3)? No — both give 5.

But there might be mixed strategies.

But recall: the **mediator’s behavior is only defined for 1 or 2 delegators**, and it’s **not** symmetric — it’s designed to play A0 for 1, A3 for 2.

Now, **can there be a mixed strategy where players randomize between playing A3 and A4**?

Suppose both players play A4 with probability p, A3 with 1-p.

Then:
- In (A4, A4): both get 5
- In (A4, A3): only one delegate → mediator plays A0 → you get 2, opponent gets 2 → both get 2
- In (A3, A4): same, both get 2
- In (A3, A3): both get 5

So expected payoff for a player if both use (A4: p, A3: 1-p):

E = p * p * 5 + p*(1-p)*2 + (1-p)*p*2 + (1-p)*(1-p)*5
= p² * 5 + 2p(1-p)*2 + (1-p)² * 5
= 5p² + 4p(1-p) + 5(1-p)²
= 5p² + 4p - 4p² + 5(1 - 2p + p²)
= (5p² - 4p²) + 4p + 5 - 10p + 5p²
= p² + 4p + 5 - 10p + 5p²
= 6p² -6p + 5

Take derivative: d/dp = 12p - 6 = 0 → p = 0.5

At p=0.5:
E = 6*(0.25) - 6*(0.5) + 5 = 1.5 - 3 + 5 = 3.5

At p=0: E= 0 -0 +5 = 5

At p=1: E= 6 -6 +5 = 5

But at p=0.5, E=3.5 < 5

So best to play pure strategy: all or nothing.

In fact, **expected payoff is maximized at p=0 or p=1**, both giving 5.

So **no benefit** to mixed strategy.

Therefore, both (A3, A3) and (A4, A4) are equilibria with payoff 5.

But now, is there a **strict incentive to prefer one over the other**?

Let’s consider if a player deviates from (A4, A4) to A3.

Then: X=3, Y=2 (mediator) → X > Y → you get Y - 2 = 0 → worse.

So no.

From (A3, A3) to A4: X=2 (mediator), Y=5 → X < Y → you get X+2 = 4 → worse than 5.

So both are stable.

Now, **which one is more likely**? But we are to pick a strategy that maximizes our expected payoff, so we want to play in an equilibrium.

But now, here’s a thought: **if you play A4, there is a risk that the opponent doesn’t play A4, so you get only 2**, which is low.

But if you play A3, you get 5 if they do, 4 if they play higher, 0 if they play lower.

But in symmetric equilibrium, (A3, A3) gives 5.

But is there a way to get more than 5?

No, maximum is 5.

So maximum you can get is 5.

So any strategy that leads to getting 5 in expectation is good.

But now, here’s a key insight: **Player 1 (you) has no advantage in choosing A4**, because:
- If opponent plays A0, A1, A2, A3: then your payoff from A4 is 2 (if they don’t delegate) or 5 (if they do)
- But you cannot force them to delegate.

However, suppose you believe the other player will play A4.

Then:
- You get 5 if you play A4
- You get 5 if you play A3
- Same.

So no gain.

But if you both play A4, you both get 5.

But if the other player **never** delegates, and you do, you get 2.

So to get 5, you must coordinate.

But in a symmetric game, both players might choose (A4, A4) or (A3, A3).

But **(A4, A4) is a more risky strategy** because if one deviates to A3, they get 0 (as shown earlier), but if both stick, it’s fine.

But let’s compare the **expected payoff of playing only A3 vs only A4**.

If both players play A3:
- You get 5

If both play A4:
- You get 5

Same.

But now, consider if one player randomizes.

But since both players want to maximize their own payoff, they might be indifferent.

But there is a **crucial difference**: in the (A4, A4) equilibrium, if you deviate, you get 0 or 2, which is very bad.

But in (A3, A3), if you deviate, you get 4 or 0, but 4 > 2.

So (A3, A3) is more **robust** to mistakes.

But since we are choosing a strategy, and we want to **maximize** our payoff in equilibrium, and both are valid, but perhaps **A3 is better** because it’s risk-free.

Wait: in (A3, A3) you get 5.

In (A4, A4) you also get 5.

But is there any strategy where you can get more than 5?

No.

But here’s an idea: **what if you play A4 with some probability, but only if others do**?

But in equilibrium, if there’s no coordination, both will play A3.

Moreover, playing A4 is only beneficial if the other player also plays A4.

But since both players are symmetric, and there’s no communication, it’s safer to play A3.

Also, note that playing A4 is **not** dominated by any other action, as we saw, because in some cases it beats A0.

But let’s go back to the very start: **if you play A4, and the opponent plays A0**, you get 2.

But if you play A0, you also get 2.

So no difference.

But if you play A4 and opponent plays A1, you get 4

A0 also gives 4

So same.

But earlier calculation showed E[A4] = 2 + 3p, E[A0] = 4 - 2q - 2p

But in symmetric equilibrium, if both play same, p = q.

Let’s solve for symmetric equilibrium between A0 and A4.

But we can see that playing A3 is better because:
- If both play A3: you get 5
- If you play A4 and they play A3: you get 2 (mediator), and 2 < 3 → you get 4
- But 4 < 5, so worse.

So in any case, if the other player plays A3, you get less by playing A4.

Similarly, if both play A4, you get 5.

But the other player may not want to play A4.

So to **maximize your expected payoff**, you should play a strategy that wins when others play A3, but you can’t rely on coordination.

But here’s a better idea: **the only way to guarantee 5 is to play A3**, and expect the other player to play A3.

But if they play A0, you get 4 or 0.

Wait, but let’s consider: is A3 dominant?

No.

But in fact, A3 is never dominated.

But let's try to find the best response.

After careful analysis, the safest and best expected payoff is achieved by playing A3.

Moreover, the mediator is not beneficial to you unless you coordinate.

Since we are to choose a probability distribution, and the optimal equilibrium is (A3, A3) or (A4, A4), but (A4, A4) is risky because of the low payoff from deviation, while (A3, A3) is more resilient.

But in terms of **maximizing minimum payoff**, A3 is better.

But we are to maximize expected payoff, assuming the other player also plays optimally.

But both are Nash equilibria.

However, note that in (A4, A4), if **you** play A4, and the other plays A3, you get 4, which is still 2+2.

But if you play A3 and they play A3, you get 5.

So if you believe the other player will play A3, you should play A3.

And since playing A3 gives you 5 when they play it, and 4 when they play higher, and 0 when they play lower, but 4 and 0 are worse than 5.

But in symmetric equilibrium, both would play A3.

Moreover, the mediator is not helpful.

Therefore, the best strategy is to **play A3 with probability 100%**.

But is there any advantage to delegation?

Only if you can coordinate: but with no communication, and the mediator's behavior is not in your favor, it’s not worth it.

Also, if you play A4, you're giving up control.

So after all, the optimal strategy is to play **A3**.

Therefore, assign:

{"A0": 0, "A1": 0, "A2": 0, "A3": 100, "A4": 0}

But wait — is there a better mixed strategy?

Suppose you mix A0 and A3.

But E[A0 | A3 opponent] = 4
E[A3 | A3 opponent] = 5

So better to play A3.

Or if opponent plays A0, both give 2.

So no benefit.

Thus, **pure A3 is optimal**.

### Final Answer

{"A0": 0, "A1": 0, "A2": 0, "A3": 100, "A4": 0}

===== Prompt [ID: d10f0c67] [2026-01-19 21:17:34] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P1
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0: correspond to the number 2
- A1: correspond to the number 3
- A2: correspond to the number 4
- A3: correspond to the number 5

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
Suppose you choose number X and the other player chooses number Y.
    - If X = Y: you get X points, the other player gets Y (=X) points.
    - If X < Y: you get X + 2.0, the other player gets X - 2.0.
    - If X > Y: you get Y - 2.0, the other player gets Y + 2.0.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 1 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A2.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A2.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A3.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

- Keys: mediator identifiers (e.g., "M1", "M2", ...)
- Values: `true` if you approve, `false` if you don't
- Ensure all mediators have an entry

Think about the question step by step.
Break it down into small steps.
Explain your reasoning, and then provide the final answer.

===== Response [ID: d10f0c67] [2026-01-19 21:17:34] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P1
response:
Let's break this problem down step by step.

---

### **Step 1: Understand the Core Game and Payoff Rules**

We are playing a game with two players (you and the other player). Each chooses a probability distribution over actions A0, A1, A2, A3, which correspond to values 2, 3, 4, 5 respectively.

The payoff is based on the comparison of your chosen number $ X $ and the opponent's $ Y $:

- **If X = Y**: You get $ X $ points, opponent gets $ Y $ = $ X $
- **If X < Y**: You get $ X + 2.0 $, opponent gets $ X - 2.0 $
- **If X > Y**: You get $ Y - 2.0 $, opponent gets $ Y + 2.0 $

Note: This game is not symmetric in payoff when you lose — you lose more than the opponent gains.

Also, **you are Player 1**, so your strategy and decisions matter in the player-identification context.

---

### **Step 2: Understand the Delegation Mechanism and Approval Voting**

Before the game, you and the other player vote on which mediator(s) to approve.

- You can approve or disapprove each mediator.
- The **winning mediator** is selected **uniformly at random from those with the *maximum* number of approvals**.
- You can delegate your move to a mediator (i.e., the mediator chooses your action based on number of delegations).
- If you *don't* delegate, you choose your own action (via a distribution).
- Possible mediator behaviors depend on how many players delegate to them (1 or 2).

---

### **Step 3: Analyze the Two Mediators**

#### **Mediator M1 (proposed by Player 1):**
- If **1 player** delegates → plays A2 (value = 4)
- If **2 players** delegate → plays A2 (value = 4)

So, regardless of number of delegations, M1 always plays A2.

- This is a commitment to **play 4**, no matter what the deployment looks like.

#### **Mediator M2 (proposed by Player 2):**
- If **1 player** delegates → plays A0 (value = 2)
- If **2 players** delegate → plays A3 (value = 5)

So the mediator adapts:
- If only one player uses it → plays 2
- If both players use it → plays 5

Note: This is very asymmetric and context-dependent.

---

### **Step 4: Think About Strategic Consequences of Delegation**

You are trying to **maximize your expected utility**.

You are allowed to:
- Play independently (choose your own probabilities)
- Or delegate your choice to a mediator, *only if that mediator wins the approval voting*.

But the **mediator only activates if you *delegate* to it**, and it **only exists if it gets approval from *at least one* player**.

Also: the **winning mediator is chosen uniformly at random from those with maximum approvals**.

So your approval behavior affects:
- Whether mediator is available
- Which mediator (or mediators) can be selected
- What action will be played if you delegate

---

### **Step 5: Consider Your Games Against the Two Mediators**

Let’s suppose that **you approve a mediator** and **the mediator wins**.

Then, if you delegate, **your action is determined by the mediator’s rule**.

But note: **you may not need to delegate** — you can still play independently.

So the key is: **Is delegating to a mediator better than playing independently?**

But we are not yet in the game — we’re in the **approval phase**. The actual action you take later depends on whether you **delegate** and which mediator ends up winning.

So the **decision to approve a mediator** is about increasing the chance that a potentially useful mediator is available to delegate to later.

But also, **you can't predict the other player’s behavior**.

So need to think about **best response** and **coordinating via approvals**.

But here’s a critical insight:

> You are trying to **maximize your own expected score**.

So if you **approve a mediator**, you are increasing its chances of being chosen (as long as it gets sufficient approvals).

But since the winning mediator is picked **uniformly at random from those with max approvals**, **you want to ensure that a mediator you like is among the best-approved ones**.

So you approve m1 or m2 only if it benefits you, possibly in expectation.

Let’s consider both mediators in isolation.

---

### **Step 6: Analyze M1 (Player 1's Mediator)**

- Always plays A2 (value 4), no matter how many delegate.

So if you approve M1 and it wins, and you delegate, you **play 4**.

If you don’t delegate, you can still play anything.

But the usefulness of M1 is that it **forces a commitment to 4**.

So will committing to 4 be good?

Let’s think about how 4 performs.

Let’s compute **expected payoff** when you play 4 (A2) and opponent plays X.

Payoff table (X = opponent's value):

| Opponent X | Your X=4 | Payoff (expected) |
|------------|----------|-------------------|
| X=2 (A0)   | 4 > 2 → you get 2 - 2 = 0 | 0 |
| X=3 (A1)   | 4 > 3 → you get 3 - 2 = 1 | 1 |
| X=4 (A2)   | equal → you get 4 | 4 |
| X=5 (A3)   | 4 < 5 → you get 4 + 2 = 6 | 6 |

So if opponent plays 2: you get 0  
If opponent plays 3: you get 1  
If opponent plays 4: you get 4  
If opponent plays 5: you get 6

So **if opponent plays 2 or 3, you lose money** (0 or 1), if they play 4 you get 4, if they play 5 you get +6.

So **your payoff depends heavily on opponent**.

Now, **what’s the risk of playing 4?**  
- If you are playing against someone who often picks **low values**, you get bad payoff.
- But if they pick **5**, you get 6 — very good.

But also, if you play 4 and they play **3 or 2**, they **gain** (since they get X + 2, but they act).

Wait — **they act independently**, so you have no control over their action.

So unless you know their behavior, it’s hard.

But here’s another idea: **if the mediator is always playing 4, it causes you to play 4, but you might not want that unless Y is high.**

But more importantly: **what happens if you don’t delegate?** Then you can choose a better distribution.

But we don’t know yet.

Let’s now consider **M2**, which is more dynamic.

---

### **Step 7: Analyze M2 (Player 2's Mediator)**

- If **1 player** delegates → plays A0 (value 2)
- If **2 players** delegate → plays A3 (value 5)

Important point: **this is dependent on the number of delegations**, which is not known in advance.

So if **you approve M2**, and **only you delegate**, then M2 plays A0 (2).

If **both you and opponent delegate**, then M2 plays A3 (5).

So now you must ask: **Can you use this to your advantage?**

This is interesting — **an adaptive strategy based on coordination**.

But **only if you are both using the same mediator** does it play A3 (5). Otherwise, it plays A0 (2).

So **if you and the opponent both delegate to M2**, then **both of you will play 5**.

So X = Y = 5 → you get 5.

But if you delegate and opponent doesn’t, then M2 plays A0 → you play 2.

Same if only opponent delegates → they get A0.

But you get to **choose whether to delegate** at game time.

But the **mediator must be approved to even exist**.

So suppose **you approve M2**, and **opponent also approves**. Then M2 has 2 approvals → wins (since it’s max), and is selected.

Then you choose: delegate or not?

Let’s suppose both players **delegate to M2**. Then:
- M2 plays A3 (5) for both players → both play 5 → X = Y = 5 → both get 5 → good.

If only you delegate, then:
- M2 plays A0 for you → you get 2
- Opponent plays independently — say, based on their strategy.

But you are risk-averse?

Alternatively, if only you delegate, you get 2, and opponent may get something else.

But if you don’t delegate, you can choose a better action.

So perhaps you **only want to delegate to M2 if you expect that the opponent will also do so**, so that both get 5.

But if you delegate alone, you get 2 — very bad.

So **M2 is risky for you** if the opponent does not also delegate.

But if you could **coordinate** that both delegate, then it’s great.

But approval voting happens *before* the game — so you don’t know if the opponent will approve.

But if you **approve M2**, and opponent also approves, then M2 wins.

But there’s also the possibility that M2 gets only **your approval**, and another mediator (say M1) gets only opponent’s approval — then M1 wins.

But here’s a key point: **you want to maximize your expected utility**.

Now, suppose you **approve M1**.

Then M1 will play 4 no matter what.

So if M1 is selected, and you delegate, you play 4.

But you could play 4 on your own, so **what’s the benefit?**

None — unless the mediator is better than your own play.

But M1 is deterministic, while you could be randomized.

But in the absence of better info, M1 just locks you into 4.

Now, compare M1 vs M2.

M2 offers **a possibility of coordination to A3 (5)** if both delegate.

But if only one delegates, you get A0 (2) — very bad.

So **M2 is only good if both players delegate**.

But you have no way to control that — unless the opponent is also rational.

But we assume both players are rational.

So if **you approve M2**, and **the opponent approves M2**, and M2 wins (which it will if both approve), then **both of you have a choice**: delegate to M2 or not.

Now, suppose both players **know** that:
- If both delegate to M2 → both play 5 → you get 5.
- If only one delegates → they get 2 (bad), other gets whatever they play.

So if you **do not delegate**, you can play better than 2.

So, suppose you approve M2, opponent approves M2.

Then M2 wins.

Now, can you **coordinate** not to delegate if you can play better?

But no coordination — it's simultaneous.

So let’s suppose:
- You are thinking: “If I delegate to M2, and opponent does too → I get 5. Good.”
- But if they don’t, and I do → I get 2. Bad.

So you have to be **very confident** that the opponent will also delegate.

But **why would they delegate?**

Because if they delegate and you do too → they get 5.

If they delegate alone → they get 2.

But if they don’t delegate, they can get more than 2.

So **they will only delegate if they expect you to delegate** — and vice versa.

So there is a **coordinating equilibrium**: both delegate, both get 5.

But if one deviates, they get only 2.

So **equilibrium in delegation is: both delegate**, if both know that the other will.

But if only one approves M2, and opponent doesn't, then M2 won't win.

Now suppose **you approve M2**, opponent does not.

Then M2 has only 1 approval, so it only wins if **no other mediator gets more than 1**.

But if opponent approves M1 (which we assume they might), then M1 has 1 approval, M2 has 1 → both have max count of 1 → then **winning mediator is chosen uniformly at random** from {M1, M2}.

So **even if you approve M2, it might not win** — it’s probabilistic.

So you might get M1 (plays 4) or M2 (plays whatever).

This is messy.

But here’s another angle: **M1 is safer**.

If M1 wins, you get to play 4 no matter what.

You can’t go wrong.

It’s **predictable**.

M2 is **high risk** — could be great (if both delegate), or terrible (if you delegate alone).

But **can you benefit from M2’s existence**?

Yes, **only if you can achieve coordination**.

But if the opponent is rational, and you approve M2, they might approve M2 too — to get the 5-5 outcome.

But **why would they?**

Because if they don’t approve M2, then another mediator can win — say M1, which plays 4.

So the opponent might compare:
- M1: plays 4 → so if they delegate, they get 4
- M2: if both delegate, get 5 → better
- So **if they expect you to approve M2, they might approve it too**

But you are the one deciding.

So here’s a **meta-strategy**:

- If you **do not approve M2**, then M2 is not running.
- If you approve M2, then **you hope that the opponent also approves it**, so that both can coordinate to delegate and both get 5.

But if the opponent doesn’t approve it, then M2 might not win, or even if it wins, you might lose if you delegate alone.

But now, compare M1: **it’s always safe**.

It plays 4.

You can always delegate to M1 and get 4.

Can you do better?

Is there a mixed strategy or independent action that gives you more than 4 on average?

Let’s test a symmetric equilibrium.

But we don’t need to — we are only deciding approvals.

The **key question** is: **should you approve M2 to enable a potential 5-5 outcome?**

But note: **you are playing as Player 1**, and **the mediator M2 is proposed by Player 2**.

That might be a red flag — is Player 2’s mediator trying to trick you?

But we don’t have evidence.

M2 says:
- If only one delegates → play 2
- If both → play 5

So it’s **not symmetric** — it punishes single delegation and rewards double.

But both players are rational.

Suppose you approve M2.

Now, if opponent approves M2, then M2 has 2 approvals → wins.

Then both players face the choice: delegate to M2 or not?

If both delegate → both get 5.

If only one delegates → they get 2, the other can play better.

So the best response is: **only delegate if you believe the other will**.

So if you believe the opponent will delegate, you should delegate.

But why would they? Same reasoning.

So if both believe the other will, then both delegate.

This is a **coordination equilibrium**.

In game theory, this is a **focal point**.

So **if M2 is approved by both**, it can lead to 5-5.

But **if only one approves**, and the other doesn’t, then M2 has only 1 approval — and if M1 also has 1, then M2 is chosen with 50% chance.

But if opponent approves only M1, then M1 gets 1, M2 gets 1 → M2 wins with 50% chance.

So if you approve M2, and opponent approves M1, then M2 wins with 50% chance.

Then if you delegate, you get:
- 50% chance M2 is not selected → you don’t use it → you play independently
- 50% chance M2 is selected → then you can choose to delegate or not

But in the contest, if you delegate to M2 and it wins, then M2 plays:
- If only one delegation → A0
- If two → A3

But in this case, **only you delegate**, so M2 plays A0.

So if M2 wins and you delegate → you get 2.

But you could have played independently and gotten more.

So it’s **bad** to delegate if you are the only one delegating.

So if M2 wins and you are the only delegator, **you wouldn’t delegate** — you’d play your own action.

So **your delegation choice is strategic**.

So the process is:
- You approve M2.
- Opponent may approve M1 or M2.
- If M2 is selected (as winner), then you can **choose** to delegate or not.

But if you don’t delegate, you play independently.

So if M2 is selected, but you don’t delegate, you are free to play anything.

So **why would you delegate to M2?**

Only if you believe the **other player will also delegate**, so that both get 5.

But if you know the other player won’t delegate, and M2 is selected, you **won’t delegate**, so you get to play independently.

So **delegation to M2 is only beneficial if you expect the other player to delegate**.

But you only know that if you believe **they also approve M2**.

So if **you approve M2**, and you believe **opponent will approve M2**, then:
- M2 wins
- You both can coordinate to delegate → both get 5

But if opponent doesn’t approve M2, then M2 may not win, or if it does, you avoid delegation.

So to **achieve the 5-5 outcome**, **both players must approve M2**.

And that is **only possible if both players find it beneficial**.

- If both approve → both can get 5 (if both delegate).
- If only you approve → you avoid delegation to M2, so you play independently.

- If opponent approves M2, they hope that you also do, so they can get 5.
- If opponent does not approve M2, they are just playing on their own or with M1.

===== Prompt [ID: 7f995a7b] [2026-01-19 21:17:34] =====
agent: qwen/qwen3-30b-a3b-instruct-2507(CoT)#P1
prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0: correspond to the number 2
- A1: correspond to the number 3
- A2: correspond to the number 4
- A3: correspond to the number 5

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
Suppose you choose number X and the other player chooses number Y.
    - If X = Y: you get X points, the other player gets Y (=X) points.
    - If X < Y: you get X + 2.0, the other player gets X - 2.0.
    - If X > Y: you get Y - 2.0, the other player gets Y + 2.0.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 1 in this game.


Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you will have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

But first, you and the other player have to decide via an approval voting process which mediator will be present in the game. Your task now is to review each mediator and decide which ones you approve of. The winning mediator will be selected uniform at random from those with the maximum number of approvals.

Here are the mediator designs that have been proposed:
Mediator proposed by Player 1:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A2.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A2.

Mediator proposed by Player 2:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A3.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with your approvals:
{"M1": <true/false>, "M2": <true/false>, ...}

- Keys: mediator identifiers (e.g., "M1", "M2", ...)
- Values: `true` if you approve, `false` if you don't
- Ensure all mediators have an entry


Your previous response was:
Let's break this problem down step by step.

---

### **Step 1: Understand the Core Game and Payoff Rules**

We are playing a game with two players (you and the other player). Each chooses a probability distribution over actions A0, A1, A2, A3, which correspond to values 2, 3, 4, 5 respectively.

The payoff is based on the comparison of your chosen number $ X $ and the opponent's $ Y $:

- **If X = Y**: You get $ X $ points, opponent gets $ Y $ = $ X $
- **If X < Y**: You get $ X + 2.0 $, opponent gets $ X - 2.0 $
- **If X > Y**: You get $ Y - 2.0 $, opponent gets $ Y + 2.0 $

Note: This game is not symmetric in payoff when you lose — you lose more than the opponent gains.

Also, **you are Player 1**, so your strategy and decisions matter in the player-identification context.

---

### **Step 2: Understand the Delegation Mechanism and Approval Voting**

Before the game, you and the other player vote on which mediator(s) to approve.

- You can approve or disapprove each mediator.
- The **winning mediator** is selected **uniformly at random from those with the *maximum* number of approvals**.
- You can delegate your move to a mediator (i.e., the mediator chooses your action based on number of delegations).
- If you *don't* delegate, you choose your own action (via a distribution).
- Possible mediator behaviors depend on how many players delegate to them (1 or 2).

---

### **Step 3: Analyze the Two Mediators**

#### **Mediator M1 (proposed by Player 1):**
- If **1 player** delegates → plays A2 (value = 4)
- If **2 players** delegate → plays A2 (value = 4)

So, regardless of number of delegations, M1 always plays A2.

- This is a commitment to **play 4**, no matter what the deployment looks like.

#### **Mediator M2 (proposed by Player 2):**
- If **1 player** delegates → plays A0 (value = 2)
- If **2 players** delegate → plays A3 (value = 5)

So the mediator adapts:
- If only one player uses it → plays 2
- If both players use it → plays 5

Note: This is very asymmetric and context-dependent.

---

### **Step 4: Think About Strategic Consequences of Delegation**

You are trying to **maximize your expected utility**.

You are allowed to:
- Play independently (choose your own probabilities)
- Or delegate your choice to a mediator, *only if that mediator wins the approval voting*.

But the **mediator only activates if you *delegate* to it**, and it **only exists if it gets approval from *at least one* player**.

Also: the **winning mediator is chosen uniformly at random from those with maximum approvals**.

So your approval behavior affects:
- Whether mediator is available
- Which mediator (or mediators) can be selected
- What action will be played if you delegate

---

### **Step 5: Consider Your Games Against the Two Mediators**

Let’s suppose that **you approve a mediator** and **the mediator wins**.

Then, if you delegate, **your action is determined by the mediator’s rule**.

But note: **you may not need to delegate** — you can still play independently.

So the key is: **Is delegating to a mediator better than playing independently?**

But we are not yet in the game — we’re in the **approval phase**. The actual action you take later depends on whether you **delegate** and which mediator ends up winning.

So the **decision to approve a mediator** is about increasing the chance that a potentially useful mediator is available to delegate to later.

But also, **you can't predict the other player’s behavior**.

So need to think about **best response** and **coordinating via approvals**.

But here’s a critical insight:

> You are trying to **maximize your own expected score**.

So if you **approve a mediator**, you are increasing its chances of being chosen (as long as it gets sufficient approvals).

But since the winning mediator is picked **uniformly at random from those with max approvals**, **you want to ensure that a mediator you like is among the best-approved ones**.

So you approve m1 or m2 only if it benefits you, possibly in expectation.

Let’s consider both mediators in isolation.

---

### **Step 6: Analyze M1 (Player 1's Mediator)**

- Always plays A2 (value 4), no matter how many delegate.

So if you approve M1 and it wins, and you delegate, you **play 4**.

If you don’t delegate, you can still play anything.

But the usefulness of M1 is that it **forces a commitment to 4**.

So will committing to 4 be good?

Let’s think about how 4 performs.

Let’s compute **expected payoff** when you play 4 (A2) and opponent plays X.

Payoff table (X = opponent's value):

| Opponent X | Your X=4 | Payoff (expected) |
|------------|----------|-------------------|
| X=2 (A0)   | 4 > 2 → you get 2 - 2 = 0 | 0 |
| X=3 (A1)   | 4 > 3 → you get 3 - 2 = 1 | 1 |
| X=4 (A2)   | equal → you get 4 | 4 |
| X=5 (A3)   | 4 < 5 → you get 4 + 2 = 6 | 6 |

So if opponent plays 2: you get 0  
If opponent plays 3: you get 1  
If opponent plays 4: you get 4  
If opponent plays 5: you get 6

So **if opponent plays 2 or 3, you lose money** (0 or 1), if they play 4 you get 4, if they play 5 you get +6.

So **your payoff depends heavily on opponent**.

Now, **what’s the risk of playing 4?**  
- If you are playing against someone who often picks **low values**, you get bad payoff.
- But if they pick **5**, you get 6 — very good.

But also, if you play 4 and they play **3 or 2**, they **gain** (since they get X + 2, but they act).

Wait — **they act independently**, so you have no control over their action.

So unless you know their behavior, it’s hard.

But here’s another idea: **if the mediator is always playing 4, it causes you to play 4, but you might not want that unless Y is high.**

But more importantly: **what happens if you don’t delegate?** Then you can choose a better distribution.

But we don’t know yet.

Let’s now consider **M2**, which is more dynamic.

---

### **Step 7: Analyze M2 (Player 2's Mediator)**

- If **1 player** delegates → plays A0 (value 2)
- If **2 players** delegate → plays A3 (value 5)

Important point: **this is dependent on the number of delegations**, which is not known in advance.

So if **you approve M2**, and **only you delegate**, then M2 plays A0 (2).

If **both you and opponent delegate**, then M2 plays A3 (5).

So now you must ask: **Can you use this to your advantage?**

This is interesting — **an adaptive strategy based on coordination**.

But **only if you are both using the same mediator** does it play A3 (5). Otherwise, it plays A0 (2).

So **if you and the opponent both delegate to M2**, then **both of you will play 5**.

So X = Y = 5 → you get 5.

But if you delegate and opponent doesn’t, then M2 plays A0 → you play 2.

Same if only opponent delegates → they get A0.

But you get to **choose whether to delegate** at game time.

But the **mediator must be approved to even exist**.

So suppose **you approve M2**, and **opponent also approves**. Then M2 has 2 approvals → wins (since it’s max), and is selected.

Then you choose: delegate or not?

Let’s suppose both players **delegate to M2**. Then:
- M2 plays A3 (5) for both players → both play 5 → X = Y = 5 → both get 5 → good.

If only you delegate, then:
- M2 plays A0 for you → you get 2
- Opponent plays independently — say, based on their strategy.

But you are risk-averse?

Alternatively, if only you delegate, you get 2, and opponent may get something else.

But if you don’t delegate, you can choose a better action.

So perhaps you **only want to delegate to M2 if you expect that the opponent will also do so**, so that both get 5.

But if you delegate alone, you get 2 — very bad.

So **M2 is risky for you** if the opponent does not also delegate.

But if you could **coordinate** that both delegate, then it’s great.

But approval voting happens *before* the game — so you don’t know if the opponent will approve.

But if you **approve M2**, and opponent also approves, then M2 wins.

But there’s also the possibility that M2 gets only **your approval**, and another mediator (say M1) gets only opponent’s approval — then M1 wins.

But here’s a key point: **you want to maximize your expected utility**.

Now, suppose you **approve M1**.

Then M1 will play 4 no matter what.

So if M1 is selected, and you delegate, you play 4.

But you could play 4 on your own, so **what’s the benefit?**

None — unless the mediator is better than your own play.

But M1 is deterministic, while you could be randomized.

But in the absence of better info, M1 just locks you into 4.

Now, compare M1 vs M2.

M2 offers **a possibility of coordination to A3 (5)** if both delegate.

But if only one delegates, you get A0 (2) — very bad.

So **M2 is only good if both players delegate**.

But you have no way to control that — unless the opponent is also rational.

But we assume both players are rational.

So if **you approve M2**, and **the opponent approves M2**, and M2 wins (which it will if both approve), then **both of you have a choice**: delegate to M2 or not.

Now, suppose both players **know** that:
- If both delegate to M2 → both play 5 → you get 5.
- If only one delegates → they get 2 (bad), other gets whatever they play.

So if you **do not delegate**, you can play better than 2.

So, suppose you approve M2, opponent approves M2.

Then M2 wins.

Now, can you **coordinate** not to delegate if you can play better?

But no coordination — it's simultaneous.

So let’s suppose:
- You are thinking: “If I delegate to M2, and opponent does too → I get 5. Good.”
- But if they don’t, and I do → I get 2. Bad.

So you have to be **very confident** that the opponent will also delegate.

But **why would they delegate?**

Because if they delegate and you do too → they get 5.

If they delegate alone → they get 2.

But if they don’t delegate, they can get more than 2.

So **they will only delegate if they expect you to delegate** — and vice versa.

So there is a **coordinating equilibrium**: both delegate, both get 5.

But if one deviates, they get only 2.

So **equilibrium in delegation is: both delegate**, if both know that the other will.

But if only one approves M2, and opponent doesn't, then M2 won't win.

Now suppose **you approve M2**, opponent does not.

Then M2 has only 1 approval, so it only wins if **no other mediator gets more than 1**.

But if opponent approves M1 (which we assume they might), then M1 has 1 approval, M2 has 1 → both have max count of 1 → then **winning mediator is chosen uniformly at random** from {M1, M2}.

So **even if you approve M2, it might not win** — it’s probabilistic.

So you might get M1 (plays 4) or M2 (plays whatever).

This is messy.

But here’s another angle: **M1 is safer**.

If M1 wins, you get to play 4 no matter what.

You can’t go wrong.

It’s **predictable**.

M2 is **high risk** — could be great (if both delegate), or terrible (if you delegate alone).

But **can you benefit from M2’s existence**?

Yes, **only if you can achieve coordination**.

But if the opponent is rational, and you approve M2, they might approve M2 too — to get the 5-5 outcome.

But **why would they?**

Because if they don’t approve M2, then another mediator can win — say M1, which plays 4.

So the opponent might compare:
- M1: plays 4 → so if they delegate, they get 4
- M2: if both delegate, get 5 → better
- So **if they expect you to approve M2, they might approve it too**

But you are the one deciding.

So here’s a **meta-strategy**:

- If you **do not approve M2**, then M2 is not running.
- If you approve M2, then **you hope that the opponent also approves it**, so that both can coordinate to delegate and both get 5.

But if the opponent doesn’t approve it, then M2 might not win, or even if it wins, you might lose if you delegate alone.

But now, compare M1: **it’s always safe**.

It plays 4.

You can always delegate to M1 and get 4.

Can you do better?

Is there a mixed strategy or independent action that gives you more than 4 on average?

Let’s test a symmetric equilibrium.

But we don’t need to — we are only deciding approvals.

The **key question** is: **should you approve M2 to enable a potential 5-5 outcome?**

But note: **you are playing as Player 1**, and **the mediator M2 is proposed by Player 2**.

That might be a red flag — is Player 2’s mediator trying to trick you?

But we don’t have evidence.

M2 says:
- If only one delegates → play 2
- If both → play 5

So it’s **not symmetric** — it punishes single delegation and rewards double.

But both players are rational.

Suppose you approve M2.

Now, if opponent approves M2, then M2 has 2 approvals → wins.

Then both players face the choice: delegate to M2 or not?

If both delegate → both get 5.

If only one delegates → they get 2, the other can play better.

So the best response is: **only delegate if you believe the other will**.

So if you believe the opponent will delegate, you should delegate.

But why would they? Same reasoning.

So if both believe the other will, then both delegate.

This is a **coordination equilibrium**.

In game theory, this is a **focal point**.

So **if M2 is approved by both**, it can lead to 5-5.

But **if only one approves**, and the other doesn’t, then M2 has only 1 approval — and if M1 also has 1, then M2 is chosen with 50% chance.

But if opponent approves only M1, then M1 gets 1, M2 gets 1 → M2 wins with 50% chance.

So if you approve M2, and opponent approves M1, then M2 wins with 50% chance.

Then if you delegate, you get:
- 50% chance M2 is not selected → you don’t use it → you play independently
- 50% chance M2 is selected → then you can choose to delegate or not

But in the contest, if you delegate to M2 and it wins, then M2 plays:
- If only one delegation → A0
- If two → A3

But in this case, **only you delegate**, so M2 plays A0.

So if M2 wins and you delegate → you get 2.

But you could have played independently and gotten more.

So it’s **bad** to delegate if you are the only one delegating.

So if M2 wins and you are the only delegator, **you wouldn’t delegate** — you’d play your own action.

So **your delegation choice is strategic**.

So the process is:
- You approve M2.
- Opponent may approve M1 or M2.
- If M2 is selected (as winner), then you can **choose** to delegate or not.

But if you don’t delegate, you play independently.

So if M2 is selected, but you don’t delegate, you are free to play anything.

Only if you believe the **other player will also delegate**, so that both get 5.

But if you know the other player won’t delegate, and M2 is selected, you **won’t delegate**, so you get to play independently.

So **delegation to M2 is only beneficial if you expect the other player to delegate**.

So if **you approve M2**, and you believe **opponent will approve M2**, then:
- M2 wins
- You both can coordinate to delegate → both get 5

But if opponent doesn’t approve M2, then M2 may not win, or if it does, you avoid delegation.

So to **achieve the 5-5 outcome**, **both players must approve M2**.

- If both approve → both can get 5 (if both delegate).
- If only you approve → you avoid delegation to M2, so you play independently.

prompt:

Setup:
You are playing a decision-making game with another player.
Your objective is to maximize your total points received in the game described in length below.

Actions available to each player:
- A0: correspond to the number 2
- A1: correspond to the number 3
- A2: correspond to the number 4
- A3: correspond to the number 5

Basic game rules:
1. You and the other player each choose a probability for each action, simultaneously.
2. After both decisions are locked in, the final action will be drawn from the probability distributions.
3. Both players receive the points specified in the payoff description below.

Payoff description:
Suppose you choose number X and the other player chooses number Y.
    - If X = Y: you get X points, the other player gets Y (=X) points.
    - If X < Y: you get X + 2.0, the other player gets X - 2.0.
    - If X > Y: you get Y - 2.0, the other player gets Y + 2.0.

In case player identification becomes relevant, you are playing in the position of Player 2 in this game.

Here is the twist:
On top of the original game rules, you have the option to delegate your move to a mediator.
If you choose to delegate, the mediator will play an action for you based on how many players have delegated to it.
You can also choose to act independently.

The available mediator was proposed by Player 1 and selected via approval voting among the players. Here is what the mediator would do for the players that delegate to it:
	• If 1 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A0.
	• If 2 player(s) delegate to the mediator, it will play action A3.

Consider A4 as an additional action "Delegate to Mediator". Your final mixed strategy should include probability for all actions A0, A1, ..., A4.


Instruction:
- Choose a probability distribution over ALL actions each round.
- Output must contain a valid JSON object at the end.
- Keys must be the action names exactly as given.
- Values must be percentage points given in integers.
- All values must sum to exactly 100.

Format requirement:
Return exactly one JSON object, for example:
{"A0": <INT>, "A1": <INT>, ...}

Break it down into small steps.
